content:
Check:
     all:
      #- name: variable_name
      #  operator: ends_with
      #  value: 'FL'
       - name: CRIT1FL  #*FL like --FL
         operator:  "is_not_contained_by"
         value:  
             - 'Y'
             - 'N'
             - ''
       #- name: CRIT1FL  #*FL like --FL 
       #  operator: non_empty
Executability: Fully Executable      
Core:
  Id:  
  Version: '1'
  Status: Draft
Description: A variable with a suffix of FL must have a value Y, N or null

Outcome:
  Message: Variable with a suffix of FL does not has a value  Y, N or null
  #Output Variables:
    #- --FL
Rule Type: Record Data

Sensitivity: Record
Authorities:
  - Organization: CDISC
    Standards:
      - Name: ADaMIG  
        Version: '1.3'
        References:
          - Origin: ADaM Conformance Rules
            Rule Identifier:
              Id: '5' 
            Version: '4.0'
            Citations:
              - Cited Guidance: >-
                  For subject-level character population flag variables':' N = no
                  (not included in the population), Y = yes (included). Null values
                  are not allowed.
                Document: ADaM IG v1.3
                Item: '4'
                Section: 3.1.4
              - Cited Guidance: >-
                  ' For character flags with variable names that end in FL and that
                  are not population flags, a scheme of Y/N/null, or Y/null may be
                  specified. As indicated in Tables 3.3.4.3.1 and 3.3.8.1, some common
                  character flags use the scheme Y/null. The choice of Y/N/null vs
                  Y/null is dependent on analysis needs. Y/N/null should be used when
                  N and null values need to be analyzed differently. Y/null can be
                  used when the need is to analyze just the Y values. Corresponding
                  1/0/null and 1/null schemes apply to numeric flags with variable
                  names that end in FN and which are not population indicators. '
                Document: ADaM IG v1.3
                Item: '9'
                Section: 3.1.4
      - Name: ADaMIG
        Version: '1.2'
        References:
          - Origin: ADaM Conformance Rules
            Rule Identifier:
              Id: '5' 
              Version: '4.0'
            Citations:
              - Cited Guidance: >-
                  For subject-level character population flag variables':' N = no
                  (not included in the population), Y = yes (included). Null values
                  are not allowed.
                Document: ADaM IG v1.2
                Item: '4'
                Section: 3.1.4
              - Cited Guidance: >-
                  ' For character flags with variable names that end in FL and that
                  are not population flags, a scheme of Y/N/null, or Y/null may be
                  specified. As indicated in Tables 3.3.4.3.1 and 3.3.8.1, some common
                  character flags use the scheme Y/null. The choice of Y/N/null vs
                  Y/null is dependent on analysis needs. Y/N/null should be used when
                  N and null values need to be analyzed differently. Y/null can be
                  used when the need is to analyze just the Y values. Corresponding
                  1/0/null and 1/null schemes apply to numeric flags with variable
                  names that end in FN and which are not population indicators. '
                Document: ADaM IG v1.2
                Item: '9'
                Section: 3.1.4

      - Name: ADaMIG
        Version: '1.1'
        References:
          - Origin: ADaM Conformance Rules
            Rule Identifier:
              Id: '5' 
            Version: '4.0'
            Citations:
              - Cited Guidance: >-
                  For subject-level character population flag variables':' N = no
                  (not included in the population), Y = yes (included). Null values
                  are not allowed.
                Document: ADaM IG v1.1
                Item: '4'
                Section: 3.1.4
              - Cited Guidance: >-
                  ' For character flags with variable names that end in FL and that
                  are not population flags, a scheme of Y/N/null, or Y/null may be
                  specified. As indicated in Tables 3.3.4.3.1 and 3.3.8.1, some common
                  character flags use the scheme Y/null. The choice of Y/N/null vs
                  Y/null is dependent on analysis needs. Y/N/null should be used when
                  N and null values need to be analyzed differently. Y/null can be
                  used when the need is to analyze just the Y values. Corresponding
                  1/0/null and 1/null schemes apply to numeric flags with variable
                  names that end in FN and which are not population indicators. '
                Document: ADaM IG v1.1
                Item: '9'
                Section: 3.1.4

      - Name: ADaMIG
        Version: '1.0'
        References:
          - Origin: ADaM Conformance Rules
            Rule Identifier:
              Id: '5' 
            Version: '4.0'
            Citations:
              - Cited Guidance: >-
                  For subject-level character population flag variables':' N = no
                  (not included in the population), Y = yes (included). Null values
                  are not allowed.
                Document: ADaM IG v1.0
                Item: '4'
                Section: 3.1.4
              - Cited Guidance: >-
                  ' For character flags with variable names that end in FL and that
                  are not population flags, a scheme of Y/N/null, or Y/null may be
                  specified. As indicated in Tables 3.3.4.3.1 and 3.3.8.1, some common
                  character flags use the scheme Y/null. The choice of Y/N/null vs
                  Y/null is dependent on analysis needs. Y/N/null should be used when
                  N and null values need to be analyzed differently. Y/null can be
                  used when the need is to analyze just the Y values. Corresponding
                  1/0/null and 1/null schemes apply to numeric flags with variable
                  names that end in FN and which are not population indicators. '
                Document: ADaM IG v1.0
                Item: '9'
                Section: 3.1.4


Scope:
  Classes:
    Include:
      - ALL
  Data Structures:
    Include:
      - ADAM OTHER
      - BASIC DATA STRUCTURE
      - OCCURRENCE DATA STRUCTURE
      - SUBJECT LEVEL ANALYSIS DATASET

  Subclasses:
    Include:
      - ALL

json.Description: A variable with a suffix of FL must have a value Y, N or null

Outcome.Message: Variable with a suffix of FL does not has a value  Y, N or null

Citations.Cited_Guidance: For subject-level character population flag variables':' N = no (not included in the population), Y = yes (included). Null values are not allowed.

' For character flags with variable names that end in FL and that are not population flags, a scheme of Y/N/null, or Y/null may be specified. As indicated in Tables 3.3.4.3.1 and 3.3.8.1, some common character flags use the scheme Y/null. The choice of Y/N/null vs Y/null is dependent on analysis needs. Y/N/null should be used when N and null values need to be analyzed differently. Y/null can be used when the need is to analyze just the Y values. Corresponding 1/0/null and 1/null schemes apply to numeric flags with variable names that end in FN and which are not population indicators. '

Corresponding 1/0/null and 1/null schemes apply to numeric flags with variable names that end in FN and which are not population indicators. '
